The noirish Chinese police procedural Day & Night shrewdly lets you in on a whopping secret in the first episode.

TailParas.Para: Former police captain Guan Hongfeng (Pan Yueming) has returned to work as a crime consultant to his old teammates, even as his twin brother, prime murder suspect Hongyu (Pan), remains on the loose. Guan's colleagues, for various reasons, are spying on him, tapping his phone and hoping he will lead them to his twin, in addition to helping them catch a serial killer.

Then, about 20 minutes in, the show reveals an outrageous stunt: Hongfeng is not just harbouring Hongyu, but also letting his brother assume his identity and fill in for him at the police station after sundown, when Hongfeng is incapacitated by fear of darkness.

And the title of the show, you realise, may be a reference to the pair. Hongfeng is on the day shift as himself, the dour expert detective, and Hongyu is the rookie on the night shift, struggling to stay in character as his big brother and to keep his food down at the sight of dead bodies.

Day & Night has been a runaway success in China, where it has been streamed more than 5.4 billion times since its premiere on Youku last August. (In comparison, K-romance Descendants Of The Sun has been viewed more than 4.8 billion times on another Chinese streaming service, Qiyi, since 2016.)

Grisly, stylish and pacy, the Chinese detective drama evidently complies with international standards, though it also has an unshakeable realness that is perhaps born of taking place in an actual police state.

The show plays - and sustains - an elaborate game of cat-and-mouse on many levels. The procedural centres on homicide cases and, also, more entertainingly, the brothers' efforts to keep up their masquerade around a whole squad of detectives.
Aren't the brothers tempting fate when they do their swop in the middle of an operation? Don't the colleagues find Guan different - brasher, fonder of whisky and friendlier to women - at night?
What cinches the show is the nuanced interplay between the brothers and others.

Reckless and playful, Hongyu is a loose cannon in early episodes. His knowledge of the logistics of drug trafficking comes in useful for one of his brother's cases, but also rings alarm bells. Yet, he is such a people person - more protective of a female rookie at work than his brother - that the murder allegations against him seem implausible.

Hongfeng has put his career on the line to gain access to a file on his brother's case, or so he says. Because he keeps his cards close to his chest, even his brother begins to wonder about his motives.
And the two brothers' uneasy relationship - who can they trust if they can't trust each other? - is the show's throbbing heartbeat.

Middle-of-the-road Hong Kong crime drama OCTB should fill you with the warm glow of a high-school reunion. Here are Jordan Chan, Sam Lee, Philip Chan, Ng Man Tat and Carrie Ng. Ah, what a gathering of actors remembered for their 1990s movies.
There's Alan Ko, son of the late stuntman Blackie Ko, remember? Oh, you won't be allowed to forget while watching OCTB, where he plays a young man called Blackie Jr.
All the stardust in the world couldn't obscure the hollowness of the show, though.

Jordan Chan stars as a former undercover detective who heads back to gangland to rein in a past associate, in a story that faintly echoes Infernal Affairs and Election, two crime movie series from the 2000s.
He is the good guy, some of the gangsters are so-so guys, and the baddies include a colourless British-spy type and his girlfriend.
Intrigue looms in the show, but not for long. Soon, all's right in Hong Kong on the eve of the handover and Chan and his friends are snacking on egg tarts again.
